Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + p(x) \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial x} = 0 \\), where \\( p(x) \\) is a position-dependent velocity field. We analyze the impact of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to the function \\( u(x, t) \\) at a specific time.

If \\( \\mathcal{F}(u) \\) is calculated for \\( u(x, t_0) \\) at \\( t = t_0 \\), and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + p(x) \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial x} = 0 \\) without further intervention, will the Fourier transform of \\( u(x, t) \\) at any later time \\( t \\) be the same as if \\( u(x, t_0) \\) was directly evolved to \\( t \\) under the PDE?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform to \\( u(x, t_0) \\) and evolving the transformed function versus directly evolving \\( u(x, t_0) \\) under the PDE leads to different outcomes. The evolution of the Fourier coefficients depends on the velocity field \\( p(x) \\), which may affect the modal interaction differently than simple translation in the x-domain.
